conversation.content: So, um, I've been thinking about this whole thing with, you know, expense reports and honestly whether anyone actually checks them anymore.
Oh that's a dangerous topic to bring up [playful] considering how many creative interpretations of "business dinner" I've seen come across my desk this month.
Wait, I mean, are you saying people are like, actually fudging their receipts or, er, just being liberal with categories?
Both, absolutely both, and the mental gymnastics people perform to justify a weekend trip to Vegas as "client relationship building" would win Olympic gold medals.
But [loudly] everyone does it though, right?
Well, that's the thing, you know, not everyone does it but, hmm, enough people do that it's become this sort of unspoken corporate tradition that nobody wants to fully address.
Okay so, I guess what I'm really asking is, uh, where's the actual line between, basically, acceptable and fraudulent?
The line is, er, technically very clear in policy but, anyway, in practice it's about as blurry as, uhh, a watercolor painting left out in the rain.
Right so, yesterday my manager, um, told me to just, the thing is, classify my Uber rides home as, actually, client entertainment.
Your manager explicitly told you to misclassify personal transportation as client entertainment, which sounds like they're either joking or actively encouraging expense fraud.
No no, I mean, she was [gasp softly] totally serious and said, you know, everyone at her level does it, honestly.
Ah, the classic "everyone at my level" defense which, basically, translates to "I've been doing this so long that, well, I've convinced myself it's somehow justified."
Should I report this?
That's a tough one because, [cough], reporting it could, err, protect you legally but, it's just that, it might also make you persona non grata in the office.
Yeah, um, I keep thinking about [trailing off] whether standing up for ethics is worth, sort of, potentially torpedoing my career here...
Standing up for ethics shouldn't torpedo anything in a healthy company, but, hmm, we both know that's not, anyway, how office politics actually work in reality.
So basically I'm stuck between, uhh, compromising my integrity or, I guess, becoming the office pariah who, well, nobody trusts anymore?
Document everything in writing, keep copies of any instructions to falsify expenses, and maybe start casually looking for other opportunities where ethics aren't treated as optional.
God, this is so, er, frustrating because I actually, you know, really liked this job until, honestly, all this shadiness started surfacing.
The shadiness was probably always there, you're just seeing it now because you're paying attention, which honestly makes you more ethically aware than ninety percent of corporate America.
